However, the might of the arithmetic in Q is bounded. Thus, some polynomials, although they have zeros, cannot be factorized into polynomials with rational coefﬁcients. Nevertheless, such polynomials can always be factorized in a wider ﬁeld. For instance, the polynomial x2 + 1 is irreducible over Z or Q, but over the ring of the so called Gaussian integers Z[i] = {a + bi | a, b ∈ Z} it can be factorized as (x + i)(x − i). Sometimes the wider ﬁeld retains many properties of the rational numbers. In particular, it will turn out that the Gaussian integers are a unique factorization domain, just like the (rational) integers Z. We shall ﬁrst discuss some basics of higher algebra. Deﬁnition 1. Further, p(x) is the minimal polynomial of α if it is irreducible over Z[x] (i.e. it cannot be written as a product of nonconstant polynomials with integer coefﬁcients). Example 1.
